title.narrative: Subvention de déplacement - présentation du rapport de l'examen final du programme Teasdale-Corti
Travel Support: Presentation of Final Evaluation Report

description.narrative:
As a research-funding partnership of three Canadian government agencies, the Global Health Research Initiative (GHRI) brings people together from different countries, sectors, and areas of expertise to tackle the complex global health problems. GHRI funded the Teasdale-Corti Global Health Research Partnership Program, which closed in 2012. This project will provide funding for Dr Sanjeev Sridharan to present the final program evaluation in Ottawa to the funders: - Foreign Affairs, Trade and Development Canada -Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) -IDRC
The Evaluation Centre for Complex Health Interventions at the University of Toronto designed the evaluation in collaboration with IDRC and CIHR.
Evaulating the Teasdale-Corti research The Teasdale-Corti program's objectives were to: -foster international partnerships and collaboration to promote the generation, communication and use of relevant health research in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs); -train and support researchers responsive to LMICs' health policy and practice priorities; and, -promote active collaboration between researchers and research users to support health priorities in LMICs.
Its four program areas included: health policy and system research, prevention and control of pandemics, prevention and control of chronic diseases, and interactions of health, environment, and development.
IDRC's Evaluation Unit assessed the evaluation as being of good quality. The evaluation provides more than 20 recommendations at three levels: the program's theory of change, future versions of the program, and associated calls for proposals. The presentation will allow GHRI to share the learning and results of this evaluation.
